body: SOME will be celebrating the end of a year of anxiety. Some, an entire decade of it. And some will be celebrating simply because they just paid $100 to enter a bar for the evening, so they darn well better get some celebration out of it. Whatever the reason, New York has no shortage of ways to ring in 2010, and one of the best is with a live
title: Sounds for a Celebration

body: THERE are many spectacles in New York every December, from the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center to Bergdorf Goodman's fantastical windows. But of special interest are the holiday markets that pop up all over the city, from Grand Central Terminal to Union Square, with hundreds of artisans and retailers selling unusual gifts. One of them is Lotta
title: SHOPPING WITH LOTTA ANDERSON; Handy for the Holidays

body: Shortly after 7 p.m. on Monday, 12,000 FedEx employees in Memphis will stretch and flex in concert and gulp holiday-colored sports drinks in preparation for processing 7,000 packages a minute. That day at the United Parcel Service world air headquarters in Louisville, Ky., employees will be poised to handle 100,000 boxes from Zappos, the online
title: For Delivery Companies, Welcome Stress

body: IN the wake of a sweeping rezoning that has taken place in New York over the last few years, apartments now rise from industrial areas, where trains clatter, trucks rumble and machinery beeps while backing up. So that residents don't suffer from nightly volleys of irksome noise, the city requires certain buildings to install thick, snug windows, to
title: POSTING; Getting a Hush For the Money

body: They're two of the most straight-backed people you have ever seen. But inside their rigid bodies, they're swooning. And there come those glorious moments in ''Brief Encounter,'' the British-based Kneehigh Theater's captivating adaptation of the 1945 movie, when the propriety-stifled lovers at its center are allowed to swoon for real. title: THEATER REVIEW | 'BRIEF ENCOUNTER'; Revisiting Those Strangers at a Train Station

body: IF West Chelsea seems like a canvas for ambitious architects and their indulgent developers, the midrise condominium at 459 West 18th Street makes a disciplined self-portrait. title: POSTING; Architect, Developer, Experimenter

body: MAKING PARKING A Group Effort A new iPhone application hopes to use ''crowdsourcing'' -- public reports -- to help with an eternal New York problem: How do you find a parking space? title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: Through the real estate boom, few new developers filled the city with luxury condominiums as fast as Shaya Boymelgreen. He turned Wall Street corner offices into minimalist bachelor lairs, built TriBeCa apartments snapped up by celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow and crowded the edges of Park Slope, Brooklyn, with condos. But Mr. Boymelgreen, 58, has
title: Star of Real Estate Boom Is Confronting Hard Times

body: Classical TERRY RILEY'S ''IN C'' is celebrating its 45th anniversary this year, but it has been virtually a standard repertory piece in New York for the last decade. Its peculiar magic is that it always sounds both thoroughly familiar and entirely fresh. The score is a sequence of 53 short melodic figures, and once you've heard ''In C,'' you'd know
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | NOV. 29 - DEC. 5

body: More than 20 years ago a Lower East Side plumber turned environmental apostle named Bill DiPaola founded an activist group called Time's Up and began organizing parties meant to publicize the dangers of acid rain, nuclear power and pesticides. title: The Ephemera of Protests, Carefully Hoarded, Is Going to an Archive

title: THEATER REVIEW | 'THE NEW ELECTRIC BALLROOM'; Sisterly Bonds, Tight Enough to Strangle

title: HABITATS; A Makeover As Homage To the Past

body: The founders of Electric Literature, a new quarterly literary magazine, seek nothing less than to revitalize the short story in the age of the short attention span. title: Serving Literature By the Tweet

body: In the five years since the last original episode of HBO's ''Sex and the City,'' the four women who wrote many of its scripts have only grown closer, serving as bridesmaids when one of their number was married and gathering for a weekly dinner they nicknamed Sushi and Story to talk about writing projects and catch up on gossip. But they had not
title: And in the Next Episode of 'Four Writers and the City' . . .

body: Nancy Spero, an American artist and feminist whose tough, exquisite figurative art addressed the realities of political violence, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 83 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was respiratory complications of an infection, her son Philip said. Born in Cleveland in 1926, Ms. Spero studied at the School of the Art
title: Nancy Spero, Artist and a Feminist, Is Dead at 83

title: Nancy Spero, Artist of Feminism, Is Dead at 83

body: At the end of a dark passageway at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, almost 50 artworks have suddenly parked in a bright, spare gallery. In the window of a former dentist's office in
title: Luring Artists to Lend Life to Empty Storefronts

body: HALLOWEEN AT THE A-SCARIUM Many Halloween celebrations focus on frightening creatures that travel by air: wayward spirits, witches on broomsticks, vampires disguised as bats. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Great architectural minds seldom think alike. And even more seldom do they resolve their differences by sleeping together. Yet that is exactly what will happen next month when a group of design radicals gathers under one roof for a live-in conference on what it calls ''oppositional architecture.'' Coined by An Architektur, a small collective of
title: TALK; The Sleep Cure

body: Brooklyn, which never fully recovered from merging with Manhattan and losing the Dodgers, is about to get new fuel to stoke its stubborn brand of local pride: It is now rich enough to support a major charity of its own. The Independence Community Foundation, long the largest private charity based in the borough, is changing its tax status so it can
title: A Brooklyn of Wealth and Needs Gets a Major Charity All Its Own

title: POSTING; A New Neighborhood? That's What They Say

title: $25 AND UNDER; 87 Scoops Later, a Sweet Meltdown

title: Creative Opportunity: Heavy Lifting Required

title: Spare Times

title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

title: Not So Slick, But Still Tasty

title: MUSIC REVIEW | 'UNDISCOVERED ISLANDS'; Welcome Home, Says a New Mrs. Odysseus

title: Recalling the Day That Ripped An Opening in the Iron Curtain

body: LAST year, after Michael Perkocha and Tina Stott asked several contractors for bids to remodel a dilapidated bungalow they had just bought for $630,000 in the Glenview district of Oakland, Calif., they decided to wait before going ahead with the project. Although the couple, both 49, had renovated several houses before and felt sure they would
title: The Makeover Moment

body: 'FOOD IN FILM: An Evening of Flavors From the Silver Screen' Good films, like good lasagna, are artfully layered productions, filled with metaphors and surprises. title: Spare Times

body: Worlds have collided. Let the fireworks begin. When it comes to striking sparks from crashing art forms and time zones, nobody beats the Wooster Group at the top of its game. title: THEATER REVIEW | 'LA DIDONE'; Lost in Space With Dido and Aeneas

body: IN 2007, Kelly McCormick and Joshua Hirsch were suffering a case of the doldrums. The remedy? Rent out their co-op on a picturesque block of Third Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and move to a rented loft in Dumbo. ''We just really wanted a change,'' Ms. McCormick said. Shortening their commute time to work was certainly a perk: Mr. Hirsch, who
title: THE SELL; Break Out the Eggshell White. Slash the Price.

body: THIS is not an obituary. The Brooklyn Paper lives. Since 1978, it has been a ''loud, offbeat and somewhat irreverent'' voice in the borough, in the words of its founder and publisher, Ed Weintrob. The paper did, however, undergo something of a transformation this month when it was purchased by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation. Just what this will
title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; A Scrappy Local Paper Ponders Its New Parent

body: Back in the day, Cope2, a Bronx graffiti legend as big as a linebacker, usually found himself in proximity to police officers only when they were tracking him in the metallic darkness of a subway yard or when they finally caught up to him and hauled him in. But on Thursday night he sat willingly within reach of three officers -- or at least three
title: Graffiti Artists Hold Panel With Old Nemeses in Blue

body: David Trautrimas, a 30-year-old Canadian artist, takes apart old kitchen mixers, hole punchers, waffle irons, staplers, vacuum cleaners, coffee machines and other household objects; photographs the pieces; and then ''reassembles'' them digitally, into what he calls ''Habitat Machines.'' With their industrial steampunk aesthetic and looming,
title: CURRENTS | SHOWS; Moving Into Appliances

body: Robert Martin Designs will hold a sample sale at its Dumbo showroom March 6 to 8, with discounts of 20 to 60 percent on items like its Adjustable lounge chair and ottoman ($2,500, marked down from $3,900), mahogany coffee table ($700, down from $1,500) and modular mahogany planter ($800, previously $2,000). Robert Martin Designs, 20 Jay Street
title: CURRENTS | DEALS; Robert Martin Designs Puts Its Samples on Sale

body: TO get the slightly battered convection oven for their new Brooklyn chocolate factory, Rick and Michael Mast traded 250 chocolate bars. The chocolate is as good as legal tender for Andrew Tarlow and Mark Firth, owners of Marlow & Sons, the restaurant and specialty shop that bartered away the oven. ''We can't keep it in stock,'' Mr. Tarlow said.
title: Now in Brooklyn, the 19th Century

body: Two seated figures on Wooster Street in SoHo: a man reading a newspaper, and a likeness of Mick Jagger on the door of a bar. And two dangling figures on Plymouth Street in Dumbo, Brooklyn: dolls on a wire. In the Passport series, James Hill, an English photographer living in Russia whose freelance work has often appeared in The New York Times, is
title: LENS JAMES HILL; Passport

body: The Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn thuds to a halt at Atlantic Avenue; Prospect Heights starts a few blocks south. But now there is a storefront between gas stations and warehouses there that looks as if it were transported intact from Paris. Choice Atlantic, its burgundy facade lettered à la Française, is a new food store owned by Thierry
title: FOOD STUFF; Food on a Grand Scale

body: WHEN Kimberly Oliver and Stuart Sclater-Booth decided to move in together, they knew that neither of their apartments was exactly right. Her loft, in Williamsburg, wasn't set up for his three children, who visit regularly. And his apartment, in Brooklyn Heights, wasn't large enough for her furniture, acquired mostly from various employers in the
title: HABITATS | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The Sofa That Ate Brooklyn

title: DUMBO; For a Special School, a Notice to Pack Up Its Pencils

body: IF you grew up in America and weren't raised as, say, a Branch Davidian, chances are you played ''store'' with your friends. You set up shop in the backyard and sold things for a common, agreed-upon currency: ''Hello ma'am, as you can see, I have fresh sassafras leaves and fine red dirt! That will be five acorn tops! Thank you very much and have a
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | BROOKLYN FLEA; Come Shop in Their Backyard

body: The reclusive life of an American eccentric is examined in scrupulous, sometimes strange detail in ''Disfarmer,'' an exquisitely designed but conceptually thin new puppet-theater work from Dan Hurlin at St. Ann's Warehouse. title: THEATER REVIEW | 'DISFARMER'; An Eccentric Existence: Ice Cream, Beer and Art

body: ANNIE PEDRET eyed a standard-issue sawhorse improbably dressed up in fleece. ''I'd love to have that in my bedroom to put clothes over,'' she said, apparently prepared to part with $750 to turn that conceptual artwork into a high-ticket coat hanger. Ms. Pedret, an associate professor of architectural history at the University of Illinois at
title: All Dressed Up Like Art Galleries

body: KNOWING what your neighbor paid for his apartment is a juicy morsel of gossip, and in New York, gossiping about real estate is an obsession. It is so captivating that an entire niche of blogs was created to cover it. In the past four years, sites like Curbed.com, Brownstoner.com, UrbanDigs.com, TrueGotham.com and The Matrix have been scrutinizing
title: And the Blog Goes On

body: The latest development dispute in Dumbo involves a proposal that has, for many residents, tinges of a Faustian bargain. Many among them want a local middle school for their children. But they are not sure they want it badly enough to accept its proposed packaging -- an apartment tower that would block views of their neighborhood's most prized
title: Wondering if a New School in Brooklyn Is Worth Blocking a View of the Bridge

body: Despite New York City's depressed economy, there is a flurry of activity in at least one niche of the real estate industry: business center companies, also often known as executive suites. Since the middle of last year, such companies -- which rent out furnished office space on a short-term basis, offering services like a receptionist, mail
title: SQUARE FEET; For Tight Times, Office Space on Flexible Terms

title: CURRENTS | DEALS; Vases to Sofas, They All Cost Less

body: WITH her Brooklyn rent rising even as rents were falling elsewhere, Chloe Sowers figured she could find a better deal than the one she had. For two years, Ms. Sowers had lived on Water Street in Dumbo, in a nice two-bedroom with a great view. But the rent, which began at $2,400 a month, was scheduled to rise to around $2,800. Heat wasn't included.
title: THE HUNT; Combing the Boroughs

author: Gabriel Cohen is the author of four Brooklyn-based novels, including ''Neptune Avenue,'' to be published in May.
body: THE boy was young, perhaps 3 or 4, and he stood inside the front window of a Park Slope sexual aid emporium, holding what appeared to be an adult toy. It was an odd little tableau, one of many ephemeral scenes undoubtedly taking place across New York on Sept. 15. But a passer-by with a camera happened along, and soon a photo of the child in the
title: You Talkin' to Me?

body: NEW YORK DAYBOOK Gifted? There's a Test Monday. These days, the anxiety-racked testing process begins practically at birth, and by age 5, children are hardly shocked by the gantlet that is the public school system. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
